body.p: ED 1 proposed that a first‑time adopter should use either all the exemptions in ED 1 or none. However, some respondents disagreed with this all‑or‑nothing approach for the following reasons:

li.p: Many of the exemptions are not interdependent, so there is no conceptual reason to condition use of one exemption on use of other exemptions.
Although it is necessary to permit some exemptions on pragmatic grounds, entities should be encouraged to use as few exemptions as possible.

Some of the exemptions proposed in ED 1 were implicit options because they relied on the entity’s own judgement of undue cost or effort and some others were explicit options. Only a few exemptions were really mandatory.

Unlike the other exceptions to retrospective application, the requirement to apply hedge accounting prospectively was not intended as a pragmatic concession on cost‑benefit grounds. Retrospective application in an area that relies on designation by management would not be acceptable, even if an entity applied all other aspects of IFRSs retrospectively.
